turns.content: Hey! I've been learning to play guitar and I'm currently working on "Blackbird" by The Beatles. It's such a beautiful song.
That's a fantastic choice! Blackbird is one of those songs that sounds deceptively simple but has a really intricate fingerpicking pattern. How long have you been playing guitar?
I've been practicing for about 3 weeks now. I'm using the JustinGuitar online course to learn the basics and it's been really helpful.
JustinGuitar is one of the best free resources out there for beginners. Three weeks in and already tackling Blackbird is ambitious though. Are you playing on an acoustic or electric?
Acoustic guitar. I figured I'd start there since Blackbird sounds best on acoustic anyway. The fingerpicking is really tricky though, especially the part where you walk up the fretboard.

That ascending chromatic line is definitely the hardest part. Take it slow and practice each measure individually before stringing them together. Is there a particular reason you chose this song to learn first?
Actually yes! I want to perform it at my roommate Jake's surprise birthday party. His birthday is on February 22 and we're throwing him a party.
That's such a thoughtful gift! A live performance of his favorite song would be really memorable. Where are you planning to have the party?
We booked The Rooftop Bar on 5th Avenue. It has a nice open space and they have a small stage area which is perfect for the performance.
A rooftop bar with a stage sounds like an ideal venue for a surprise party. Have you sorted out the guest list and budget yet?
Yeah, I've invited 15 people so far. I'm trying to keep the budget around $400 total, which covers food, drinks, and a small decoration setup.
$400 for 15 people is doable, especially if the venue doesn't charge a rental fee. That's roughly $26 per person. Are you handling the food yourself or going through the bar's catering?
The bar has a party package that includes appetizers and a drink per person, which helps a lot. The rest goes to decorations and the birthday cake.
That sounds like a solid plan. Party packages usually save a lot of hassle. Going back to the guitar performance, do you feel like you'll be ready by February 22?
I think so if I keep practicing every day. I can play through most of the song but I still stumble on the bridge section. I've been doing about an hour of practice each evening.

An hour a day is solid practice time. For the bridge, try isolating just those four measures and looping them at half speed with a metronome. You still have a few weeks, so you should be in good shape by the party.
Good idea with the metronome. I'm also thinking about learning a second song as a backup in case I freeze up on stage. Maybe "Wonderwall" since it's simpler chords.

Having a backup song is a smart move, especially for your first live performance. Wonderwall is a great choice because it's mostly open chords and everyone knows the melody. Between the two songs and the rooftop venue, Jake's going to have an amazing surprise birthday.

recallQuestions.question: What song is the user learning to play on guitar?
What online course is the user using to learn guitar, and how long have they been practicing?
Where is the surprise birthday party being held and when is it?
recallQuestions.expectedAnswer: The Rooftop Bar on 5th Avenue, on February 22

recallQuestions.question: How many people have been invited to the party and what is the budget?
recallQuestions.expectedAnswer: 15 people, with a budget of around $400

recallQuestions.question: What backup song is the user considering learning in case of stage fright?
